articles.summary: The Sun's campaign to support the UK's struggling baby banks has led to the creation of the Baby Bank Alliance, the first national network of banks in the UK. Over 200,000 British children were supported by baby banks last year, a 54% increase in referrals to baby banks between 2021 and 2023. The new figures reveal that over 54% of referrals will increase from 2021 to 2023, according to Sophie Livingstone, Chair of the Babies Bank Alliance. Last year, generous Sun readers and British businesses donated more than £100,000 to the Baby, Bank on Us and Cosy campaigns. The Baby Banks Alliance aims to bring together Britain's 200 baby banks across the UK to support each other and work together. The campaign, supported by Princess Kate, is supported by celebrities such as Kate Middleton, Leona Lewis, Christine Lampard, and Kate Lawler.

articles.title: Cancer Risk From Pesticides Comparable To Smoking For Some Cancers
articles.description: The steep price of food security: the strongest associations between agricultural pesticides and cancers was for non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma, leukaemia, and bladder cancer.
articles.content:
Food security comes with a steep price: the strongest associations between pesticides and cancer was for non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma, leukaemia, and bladder cancer

Modern agriculture currently feeds the b... [4484 symbols]
articles.summary: A study by Isain Zapata, an Assistant Professor of Research and Statistics at Rocky Vista University, Colorado, compared the increased risk of pesticide exposure to smoking, a noxious habit associated with a higher cancer risk. The study found that for some cancers, agricultural pesticide usage is comparable in magnitude to the effect of smoking. The strongest associations between pesticides and cancer were for non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma, leukaemia, and bladder cancer. This study also found that living near farms can increase a person’�s risk of cancers, and in some cases, the increased cancer risk surpassed those caused by smoking. It is the first comprehensive examination of cancer risks due to pesticide exposures at a national level. The researchers aim to motivate people to consider the dangers of pesticide use within this context.

articles.title: CDC reports biggest jump in US infant mortality rate in decades
articles.description: The U.S. infant mortality rate in 2022 had the largest year-over-year increase in two decades.
articles.content:
The U.S. infant mortality rate rose in 2022, according to data released Thursday by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Nearly 20,600 babies died before the age of 1, or 5.6 infant deaths... [1403 symbols]

entities.data: the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

companies.name: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

articles.summary: The U.S. infant mortality rate rose in 2022, with nearly 20,600 babies dying before the age of 1, or 5.6 infant deaths for every 1,000 live births, marking a 3% increase from 2021. This is the largest year-over-year increase in 20 years. Infant mortality continues to be higher than in most other industrialized countries, but the rate has trended downward since 1995. Despite this increase, the rate is still 19% lower than the last increase in 2002. Nearly 20% of infant deaths in the US are attributable to congenital malformations, with another 14% due to short gestation periods and low birth weight. The rise may be due to states' restrictions on abortion following the overturning of Roe v. Wade.

articles.summary: Optum, a healthcare company owned by UnitedHealth Group, is laying off 525 people in California, many of them at urgent care facilities in Southern California. The company, in a notice to the state’s Employment Development Department, announced that it is undertaking layoffs and departmental closures at 14 locations across California, including those in Glendora, Montebello, Covina, Pasadena, Long Beach, Redlands, Highlands, Los Angeles, Beaumont, Irvine, El Segundo, Cerritos and Hayward in Alameda County. The layoffs will begin in a series of eight waves beginning Sept. 16 and conclude in January 2025. Despite not providing a reason for the job cuts, Optum is open to shifting affected employees to open positions within the company. The firm declined to comment on the layoffs or whether severance pay would be offered. The move comes as part of a larger effort to address a new California law that will increase healthcare wages to a minimum floor of $25 hourly, which was delayed in June due to a budget deficit.

This is the latest ownership or name change for St. Joe's, which became Ascension St. Joseph in 2022 when AMITA Health split into two entities and became part of the St. Louis-based Ascension network. The deal includes various senior facilities, including Villa Franciscan in Jolie, Resurrection Place in Park Ridge and Fox Knoll Village in Aurora. Prime Healthcare and two of its doctors were ordered in 2021 to pay $37.5 million to settle allegations of kickbacks, billing for a suspended doctor, false claims for implantable medical hardware, and overbilling.

articles.summary: Boeing whistleblower, John Barnett, was so distressed by working conditions at its South Carolina plant that he suffered PTSD, according to his lawyer Brian Knowles. Barnett, who was diagnosed with PTSD and anxiety after being exposed to a hostile work environment, took his life during a legal battle with the carrier in March. His death came during a break in depositions in his own whistleblower retaliation suit against Boeing. The revelation comes a month after his family filed a lawsuit against Boeing, holding the company responsible for his death. Barnett had previously warned about sub-standard parts being fitted to aircraft on the assembly line and had issued warnings about the 787 Dreamliner and 737 Max models before his sudden death.

articles.title: Autism in women: Signs and diagnosis
articles.description: Women who have autism often remain undiagnosed with devastating impact. Here’s how to understand the signs and where to turn for help
articles.content: As an example, Dr Moseley says that autistic boys are also more likely to externalise their struggles, leading to notably disruptive behaviour at school, while this is more unlikely to be the case wit... [5712 symbols]
articles.summary: Autistic boys are also more likely to externalise their struggles, leading to disruptive behaviour at school, while girls tend to respond to their autism internally, making it appear more like shyness. Research has also found that autistic girls are more likely than boys to internalise their autism, making their difficulties less likely to be picked up. This is due to a cultural preference for girls being more quiet and nervous, which makes their difficulties more difficult to be detected. The brain systems involved in social behaviour develop more quickly in girls, enabling them to be better at camouflaging their social challenges. Approximately 80 per cent of autistic women remain undiagnosed at age 18, which can have severe consequences for mental health and make them more vulnerable to sexual exploitation. The diagnosis can be obtained through three main ways: through gathering information from someone familiar with the person involved in these forms of behavior. However, there is no blood test or brain scan which can be used to obtain a diagnosis of autism.

articles.summary: Jonathan M. Gerber, MD, has been named as the new chief clinical officer of NYU Langone Health's Perlmutter Cancer Center. He joins from the University of Massachusetts Chan Medical School and UMass Memorial Health, where he previously served as the director of the cancer center and chief of hematology and oncology. Dr Gerber will work with the Perlmut Cancer Center (PCC) and NYU Langon leadership teams to ensure the highest quality of patient care and the integration of clinical and translational research at PCC locations in Manhattan, Brooklyn, Queens, and Long Island. He will also coordinate efforts across different cancer specialties, departments, and campuses. Gerb's research interests include leukemia and related hematologic conditions, blood and marrow transplantation (BMT) and cellular therapy.

articles.content: If you’re anywhere near getting ready to apply to college, you may already be contemplating whether to take the ACT®, or American College Test. For more than a half-century, the ACT has been one of th... [6812 symbols]
articles.summary: The ACT, or American College Test, is a standardized, multiple-choice test used primarily for college admissions in the U.S. It is offered seven times a year and is offered in person or online. The ACT's four mandatory sections and one optional section test assesses English usage and mechanics, including grammar, punctuation and sentence structure, and familiarity with rhetorical techniques. The science section tests students' ability to interpret, analyze, and solve problems in natural sciences. Students can choose between self-paced courses, live group sessions, and one-on-one tutoring. However, some students submit both the ACT and SAT scores to their prospective schools.

articles.title: Celebrate "Every Breath, Every Story" During Pulmonary Fibrosis Awareness Month in September
articles.description: September is Pulmonary Fibrosis Awareness Month, presented by the Pulmonary Fibrosis Foundation (PFF) to drive awareness of pulmonary fibrosis (PF) and interstitial lung disease (ILD). There are more than 200 types of interstitial lung diseases (ILD), which are characterized by varied amounts of inflammation, scarring, or both, that damage the ability of the lung to absorb oxygen from the air. Pulmonary fibrosis means scarring of the lung and can be seen in many types of ILD.
articles.content: CHICAGO, July 25, 2024 /PRNewswire/ -- September is Pulmonary Fibrosis Awareness Month, presented by the Pulmonary Fibrosis Foundation (PFF) to drive awareness of pulmonary fibrosis (PF) and interstit... [4069 symbols]
articles.summary: The Pulmonary Fibrosis Foundation (PFF) is celebrating Pulmonary Frosis Awareness Month in September, aiming to raise awareness of pulmonary fibrosis (PF) and interstitial lung disease (ILD), which have no known cure. The PFF will use this month's theme "Every Breath, Every Story" to highlight patient journeys and mobilize family and supporters to spread the word about PF. During the month, the PFF posts daily stories from people living with PF and ILD, caregivers, health care professionals, transplant recipients, and those who have lost a loved one to these diseases. National PFF Walk Day will take place on September 28 and 30 Facts in 30 Days will be shared daily on Facebook and Instagram to educate the public about the disease's impact. The Foundation's mission is to accelerate the development of new treatments and ultimately a cure for the disease.

These conditions have led to increased short-term respiratory complaints and increased risk of stroke and heart attacks, according to Dr. Anthony Gerber, a professor of medicine and director of pulmonary research at National Jewish Health. The issue has been exacerbated by wildfires, wildfires in the Western US and Canada, leading to high ozone levels and challenges in reducing emissions from automobiles and power plants. articles.summary: Hong Kong's longest flu season ended after more than six months, with the Department of Health's Centre for Health Protection confirming that the current season lasted 28 weeks, a period not usually seen in the city. The Centre for Heath Protection attributed the prolonged season to a change in circulating influenza virus strains. The department also urged the public to maintain a high standard of hygiene. The flu season had ended in mid-January, and the admission rate to public hospitals of people with a flu diagnosis dropped to 0.23 per 10,000 people. However, experts warned that there would only be a short gap before the next flu season, which is likely to be less serious than the previous one. Kindergarten and child care centres will now be able to provide injectable and nasal spray flu vaccines, with medical professionals visiting them to administer them.

The company's breast cancer drug, which is available in other countries including Scotland, the United States and Romania, was blocked by Nice in March after it deemed it a "moderately severe disease" that did not offer value for money. Sir Pascal argued that the current system was creating a "roadblock" which could affect other drugs for cancer and other severe diseases, and that it could lead to drug makers to invest less in Britain. He also called on the Prime Minister to review the decision-making process. articles.summary: Wildfires are causing air quality alerts and evacuation orders across several western states and Canada, leading to smoke and haze in California, Oregon, Arizona, Washington, and several other western states. As of Wednesday, there were 79 large, active wildfires that have burned over 1.4 million acres across the country. Evacuation orders are in effect for 15 fires in the Northwest. Meanwhile, Canada is battling about 430 active wildfires in British Columbia and 177 in Alberta, including two that have led to the evacuation of up to 25,000 visitors and residents of the Canadian Rockies’ largest national park. To deal with the pollution from these wildfires, air quality advisories have been issued in many parts of the western United States.

articles.summary: As millions prepare for the 2024 Olympics in Paris, some are concerned about bedbugs. Nine months ago, a bedbug crisis in Paris sparked international attention after videos of the insects crawling on the Paris metro went viral. The outbreak sparked panic and led to action against bedbugs, or "punaises de lit." However, this has stoked fears about infestations during the Olympic Games, which begin on July 26. The surge in tourism and crowds could provide more hosts for the pests. A 2023 study by the French Agency for Food, Environmental and Occupational Health & Safety found that 11% of French households were infested with bedbugs between 2017 and 2022, up from 7% in 2014. Bedbugs are found almost anywhere their hosts live, often near where people sleep.

articles.summary: Shares of Viking Therapeutics rose 16% after the company announced plans to advance its experimental weight loss injection into a late-stage trial earlier than expected. This move brings the company closer to the highly popular market for GLP-1s, which analysts predict could grow into a $150 billion market by the end of the decade. The company, which is one of several pharmaceutical companies hoping to compete in the space against Novo Nordisk and Eli Lilly, had previously announced positive results from a phase two study. However, after receiving written feedback from the Food and Drug Administration, Viking has decided to move the injection directly into a phase three trial. This decision will likely shave a year off Viking's development timeline for the injection.

articles.title: America is still dealing with the pandemic's scars, psychologists say
articles.description: Many people have found themselves lonely and exhausted but anxious about connecting with others. Here's why experts are worried about the loss of unplanned, informal interactions.
articles.content: When Jessica Hernandez’s best friend from college died of cancer in April 2020, she attended the funeral the only way she could under a COVID-19 shelter-in-place order: via Zoom. Her heartache persist... [7681 symbols]
articles.summary: Psychologists have found that even those who lost loved ones, livelihood, or health, are still dealing with a diffuse, vague sense of wrongness four years after the deadly COVID-19 outbreak. This distress, which manifests in heightened loneliness, sapped social capacity, and withering bonds with community, is part of the emotional legacy of lockdown. A survey by the 2022 showed that one third of Americans found stress overwhelming daily, and nearly half reported they were more anxious in 2024 than they were the previous year. Health geographer Jessica Finlay has been tracking all 50 states since 2020 to track the ways they’ve coped with the crisis. She also found the highest levels of loneliness and isolation in respondents ages 15 to 20, but people of all ages complain of diminished social battery and increased apprehension. Despite these changes, experts believe that the trauma of the lockdown era has led to increased public conflict and increased public tension.

Second Heart Assist has already successfully performed FIH studies in Panama (South America) and other OUS countries for multiple indications.
articles.content: SALT LAKE CITY, July 25, 2024 /PRNewswire/ -- Utah-based Second Heart Assist Inc., announced today the successful completion of the company's first Central American case to evaluate the performance of... [3731 symbols]
articles.summary: Utah-based Second Heart Assist Inc., has completed a successful case study in Central America using its Whisper™ percutaneous mechanical circulatory device. The device is designed to improve cardiac function and renal perfusion in patients with acute decompensated heart failure (ADHF). The patient developed severe cardiomyopathy and progressive biventricular heart failure after a Covid infection several years earlier, leading to multiple hospitalizations and three hospitalizations prior to the admission. The Whisper's device was quickly inserted and was associated with an immediate increase in urine output (over 400% over the previous hour) before being removed. Despite significant diuresis during device use, the patient's measured renal function (Creatinine) remained even after device removal. This case demonstrates the power and safety of the SHA device in the management of patients with advanced heart failure who present with severe volume overload and develop diuretic resistance and have persistent congestion.

articles.summary: The UK National Health and Transplant (NHSBT) has issued a national alert due to shortages of certain blood types, O negative and O positive, due to increased demand from hospitals and high levels of unfilled appointments at donor centres. This is only the second time such an alert has been issued, with the only other occasion in October 2022. The alert is triggered when blood levels fall under two days' worth of stock, with O negative currently at 1.6 days, while overall national stocks of all types are 4.3 days. Donors have been asked to book and fill appointments at either the NHSBT’s 25 permanent donor centres across England or 235 mobile teams collecting blood at community venues. The NHSBT is also making an additional 1,000 appointments available each week.

articles.summary: The only GP surgery in St Davids, Pembrokeshire, is set to close due to the closure of its practice following a lack of recruitment and management. Approximately 3,000 patients will be transferred to other practices before the surgery's closure at the end of October. The majority of the 2,728 patients, about 2,500, will transfer to the surgery in Solva, managed by the Hywel Dda health board, with a further 161 expected to transfer to Fishguard, 28 to St Thomas's practice in Haverfordwest, and 26 to Winch Lane. Director of primary care, Jill Paterson, suggested the idea of establishing a health board-managed surgery in the city would cost an extra £267,000 on top of the £586,000 annual cost of providing a GP service. The decision to relocate patients was endorsed by the health board and was made by chairman Neil Wooding.

articles.title: 3 Ways The ‘Spotlight Effect’ Is Sabotaging Your Dating Life—By A Psychologist
articles.description: Feeling like you are caught in the glare? Here’s how to shift the spotlight to where it truly belongs.
articles.content: Dating can be an exciting yet nerve-wracking experience, filled with the anticipation of new connections and the anxiety of first impressions. One cognitive bias that often exacerbates these feelings ... [6501 symbols]
articles.summary: The 'Spotlight Effect', a psychological phenomenon that leads us to believe others are paying more attention to our appearance, actions and mistakes than they actually are, is negatively impacting our dating life. This phenomenon magnifies self-consciousness and distorts our perceptions, leading us to become overly critical of ourselves and overly concerned about how we are perceived. This can affect our ability to be authentic and relaxed, and ultimately affect the quality of our dating experiences. Psychologist Dr. Rick Steves outlines three ways the effect may be impacting your dating life and strategies to overcome it. Suggestions include practicing mindfulness before and during dates, engaging actively and engaging in conversation with your date, focusing on building a genuine connection with them. Accepting minor conversational slip-ups and reflecting positively on the positive aspects of the conversation. Redirecting focus away from self-monitoring to enjoying the moment can help reduce stress and allow authentic self-expression.

articles.title: I Never Gave Homophobes A Second Thought. Then My Husband And I Became Dads To Twin Girls.

entities.data: the National Conference of State Legislatures

articles.summary: The author and her husband and husband became fathers to twin girls in 2020, after their girls were placed with them for adoption at four and a half months old. Despite the chaos of early parenting days, they quickly settled into being dads. The girls, now aged 4 years old, are vocal about their relationship with their parents being "Daddy and Baba" when they are out and about. However, they still face scrutiny from strangers who question their connection to the children. The author suggests that federal legislation should be introduced to codify the rights of same-sex couples and queer parents, but these rights are not yet fully codified. The Respect for Marriage Act, signed by President Joe Biden in 2022, merely stipulates that states must recognize marriages and adoptions across state lines. Nearly half of states have laws in place that would make gay marriage illegal following an overturning of Obergefell, and there are signs that "settled law" can change. The only way to be absolutely sure my kids won't get taken away from me is the passage of a federal version of the Massachusetts Parentage Act.

However, during his treatment, another bacterium, Mycobacterium cosmeticus, was identified as rare and unidentifiable. Despite this, there were no antibiotics found to combat this bacteria. Not all infections, especially skin infections, need to be treated with antibiotics, but drain is the key part of treatment. Proper wound care and antibiotics are the mainstay of treatment for these complications.

According to a study by the National Institutes of Health, as many as 21% of adults in the USA experience chronic pain, with 8% suffering from high-impact chronic pain (HICP). The pain can affect the physical and mental well-being of those affected, as well as their business performance and productivity. It can also cause absenteeism among affected employees and lead to increased operational challenges. Without change, businesses may struggle and eventually close due to insufficient staffing. Alternative treatments for chronic pain are being considered as effective alternatives. Companies are increasingly looking into holistic pain management, which involves holistic treatments such as ergonomic equipment and wellness programs.

articles.title: 'Scary' Gloucestershire social care figures spark future concerns

articles.content: "Scary" figures show the scale of the challenge facing social services in Gloucestershire, with more older people expected to need care. County councillors have been told there will be a sharp rise in... [1621 symbols]
articles.summary: Gloucestershire social services are expected to face a significant increase in demand for residential and nursing care over the next 20 years, with a total of 7,000 expected to reach by 2043. The number of people requiring community care is also predicted to rise from 2,500 to more than 4,000 over the same period. Jenny Cooper, head of integrated commissioning for older people services, highlighted the dramatic growth of the over 85s, suggesting a significant rise in demand. The deficit in the number of nurses and care workers is predicted to increase from 100 currently to almost 3,000 by 2042. Care bosses have stated that there is no single solution to alleviate the pressure and it will require coordinated efforts on multiple fronts.

articles.summary: Gloucestershire social services are facing a significant increase in demand for residential and nursing care over the next 20 years, with over 7,000 expected to need care by 2043. Currently, there are over 4,000 people needing care in Gloucestersshire, with the number expected to reach 7,500 by 2042. The rise in demand is expected to raise further concerns for county councillors. Jenny Cooper, head of integrated commissioning for older people services, said the figures were "quite dramatic".

articles.title: AstraZeneca Posts Earnings Beat, Lifts Guidance on Strong Sales

• None Like its COVID-19 vaccine manufacturing colleagues Pfizer and Johnson & John... [2618 symbols]
articles.summary: AstraZeneca's second-quarter earnings beat expectations and the company has revised its full-year guidance due to strong sales. The company reported $12.94 billion in revenue for the quarter, a 13% increase from the previous year's $11.42 billion and above the $12."54 billion analysts had projected. Net income also increased more than analysts expected. Despite this, AstraZeneca saw lower vaccine revenue year-over-year compared to peers like Pfizer and Johnson & Johnson. The pharmaceutical company plans to increase revenue to $80 billion annually by 2030, nearly double the $45.81 billion reported in fiscal 2023. Despite the revenue beat and increased guidance, Astrazeneca's ADRs were 4% lower at $79.71 in pre-market trading.

Claire Burnight, 24, from Orange County, ... [5202 symbols]
articles.summary: Claire Burnight, 24, from Orange County, California, was diagnosed with a brain tumor that halted her plans for medical school. Her family held a "fake ceremony" for her to celebrate her achievements, presenting her with her own doctor's jacket and flowers. The diagnosis has made Burnight even more determined to pursue her lifelong dream of medicine. She plans to defer her medical school admission for a year so she can recover and help others through their struggles. The video of the ceremony has been shared on her TikTok account, @clairesbraintumor. If left untreated, the tumor could have left her with hearing loss and potentially lead to surgery.

articles.title: Pusan National University Study Finds First-time Teen Moms at Higher Risk of Postpartum Depression
articles.description: Postpartum depression (PPD) is a clinical condition that affects women after childbirth, typically starting within a few weeks postpartum. It is characterized by intense feelings of anxiety, sadness, and fatigue, which can be prolonged. PPD can have adverse effects on both the mother and the newborn, leading to negative health outcomes and impaired parenting practices. Over the years, research has linked PPD to a combination of individual and societal factors, categorizing these influences into
articles.content:
The prevalence of postpartum depression and various maternal factors associated with it were evaluated using healthcare data of first-time mothers

BUSAN, South Korea, July 25, 2024 /PRNewswire/ -- Po... [4072 symbols]
articles.summary: A study by the College of Pharmacy, Pusan National University, South Korea has found that first-time teen mothers are at higher risk of Postpartum Depression (PPD), a clinical condition that affects women after childbirth and can lead to negative health outcomes and impaired parenting practices. The study was conducted using healthcare data of mothers and various maternal factors associated with PPD. The researchers found that PPD was more prevalent in adolescent mothers by 1.5 times when compared to adult mothers. They also found that adolescent mothers were less likely to avail first trimester prenatal care, more likely to use tobacco products and have an infection during pregnancy. The research findings were published in Volume 51, Issue 1 of Birth: Issues in Perinatal Care journal. Public health campaigns and awareness programs are crucial for prevention and management of PPD, particularly among adolescent mothers.

articles.summary: Actinium Pharmaceuticals, a leading company in the development of Antibody Radiation Conjugates (ARCs) and other targeted radiotherapies, has received FDA clearance to study Iomab-ACT for targeted conditioning prior to a bone marrow transplant (BMT), in patients with sickle cell disease. The study will be conducted in collaboration with Columbia University and led by Markus Mapara, M.D., Ph.D. at Columbia University Irving Medical Center, Director, Bone Marrow Transplantation and Cell Therapy Program, Vagelos College of Physicians and Surgeons. If successful, the trial will inform a clinical trial to evaluate Iomob-ACT as a targeted conditioning agent prior to gene therapy. This collaboration aims to enable patients with disease to have broader access to allogeneic BMT and gene therapy, potentially curable cellular therapies. The potential market for these therapies is expected to grow at a CAGR of approximately 11% over the next five years.

articles.summary: Omaha-based healthcare company Fusion has spent over 2,500 hours in the first half of 2024, 2024, dedicating nearly 750 hours of volunteer time to engaging with the community. The company's core purpose is to improve the lives of everyone it touches and is behind the company's volunteer efforts. These efforts include supporting local food insecurity, providing educators with classroom supplies, supporting patients with traumatic brain injuries and neurological challenges, and assisting with Memorial Day flag planting, park clean-ups, and tornado relief cleanup. Fusion employees also participated in a Warr;or Walk for mental health and held a dedicated fundraiser for a local gym supporting people living with Multiple Sclerosis. In 2023, Fusion employees contributed over 3,000 community engagement hours and are on track to exceed this this year.

articles.summary: The Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) is investigating the death of a 58-year-old employee at GE Appliances in Decatur, Georgia, on Wednesday morning. The company has cancelled production for the rest of the week and is working with local law enforcement to determine the cause of the accident. The incident occurred during an "entrapment with a piece of machinery" call at around 9:22 a.m. Decatur Fire & Rescue EMS responded to the scene. The U.S. Department of Labor confirmed that OSHA is investigating employee Rodney Terry's death. The plant produces top-freezer refrigerators and employs 1,600 people.

articles.summary: Laurence Wells, a hospital chef at St George's Hospital in Lincoln, has celebrated his 50 years of working for the NHS. He started as a trainee cook at 16 and now works part time at Lincoln County Hospital. He was given gifts, cards and a special celebratory meal prepared by his colleagues. Members of his family have also worked for the National Health Service (NHS) over the years. Prof Karen Dunderdale, chief executive at Lincolnshire Community and Hospitals NHS Group, praised Wells' service and support for millions of patients and colleagues over the decades.

articles.summary: Dementia is a syndrome or group of symptoms associated with the progressive decline of the brain. The prevalence of the condition has raised concerns as a record number of people are now living with it. The NHS reported that 478,822 patients had a diagnosis of dementia on 29 February 2024, an increase of 1,199 patients since 31 January 2024, and a record 487,432 people had been diagnosed by June this year. Although there is no cure, the sooner you spot the signs of dementia, the early you can seek support.

CEO Thomas Schinecker welcomed positive early stage trial ... [1437 symbols]

keywords.name: its Wegovy rival weight loss drugs

articles.summary: Roche's CEO, Thomas Schinecker, has announced that its two weight loss drug candidates will be part of a suite of medicines aimed at combating the effects of obesity. The announcement follows positive early stage trial results from two new weight loss drugs that showed "best in disease potential," according to Schineck. The Swiss pharmaceutical company plans to use these drugs as a broader portfolio to differentiate itself from other competitors in the growing obesity medication market. GLP-1/GIP, or glucagon-like peptide 1 agonists, are used to treat diabetes and obesity and form the basis for weight loss medications like Novo Nordisk's Wegovy and Eli Lilly's Zepbound. Schinecking also highlighted the company's own portfolio of medicines that can combine with obesity drugs, including GYM329, which could counter the "yo-yo effect" of weight loss.

articles.title: James Bond legend told he 'wouldn’t live' with 'half a kidney' in cruel taunts
articles.description: George Lazenby, who played 007 in On Her Majesty's Secret Service, spent 18 months in hospital as a child due to a serious kidney issue.
articles.content: James Bond icon George Lazenby, who has just emotionally announced his retirement from acting, previously opened up about a childhood medical condition that meant doctors feared he "wouldn't live to b... [2806 symbols]
articles.summary: Australian actor George Lazenby, known for his role as 007 in 1969's On Her Majesty's Secret Service, has announced his retirement from acting following a health issue that led to doctors fearing he wouldn't live as a man. The 84-year-old actor spoke about the health issue on the 2023 episode of Steven Jay Rubin’s Saturday Night At The Movies podcast. He recalled spending 18 months in hospital due to a problem with his kidneys and being told by a doctor from England during the Second World War that he was peeing backwards into his kidneys. He also recalled being taunted by a fellow pupil at school about his death at age eight. George announced his decision to retire from acting and focus on spending more time with his family.

articles.summary: The Job Research Foundation has announced its seventh round of grant funding for up to $400,000 to aid in research into the causes and treatments of Job Syndrome, a rare multisystem immunodeficiency disorder. The Foundation will award up to two grants each over a two-year period for scientific research into Job Syndrome. The application process is open to researchers worldwide and winners will be announced between December 2024 and January 2025. The long-term goal of the Foundation is to advance research to find a cure for Job Syndrome and improve the treatments for patients suffering from the disorder. Job Syndrome was discovered in 1966 and is found in males and females worldwide.

articles.title: Will My Home Be Safe From Medicaid in a Trust?
articles.description: An individual can protect their assets from Medicaid, including their home, by placing them into a trust. Essentially, the assets become owned by the trust and not by the individual. This mechanism can decrease the individual’s asset count for Medicaid eligibility, presenting a way to potentially conserve wealth and secure necessary medical care. However, like all […] The post Does Putting Your Home in a Trust Protect It From Medicaid? appeared first on SmartReads by SmartAsset.
articles.content: An individual can protect their assets from Medicaid, including their home, by placing them into a trust. Essentially, the assets become owned by the trust and not by the individual. This mechanism ca... [6734 symbols]
articles.summary: An individual can protect their assets from Medicaid, including their home, by placing them into a trust. This can significantly decrease the individual's asset count for Medicaid eligibility. However, this decision presents benefits and potential risks. The trust can be set up and funded well in advance of any Medicaid application, but must be reviewed during the Medicaid look-back period. An applicant's primary home is typically exempt from the Medicaid asset limit, but if it exceeds a certain limit, it may need to be transferred to a trust to protect it from Medicaid. While revocable trusts offer flexibility as they can be changed or revoked by the trustor, they won't protect assets from the program. However they remove assets from an owner’s control, rendering them eligible to meet Medicaid requirements.

articles.summary: GE HealthCare is partnering with Amazon Web Services to develop new generative artificial intelligence models and tools for medical use. The company believes that the health-care industry generates nearly one-third of all data globally, which is often not easily accessible. The partnership with AWS will provide GE HealthCare with the technical infrastructure required to quickly build generative AI models at scale. The new models and applications will initially be available to employees and customers, with plans to make them more widely accessible in the future. GE's global chief science and technology officer, Dr. Taha Kass-Hout, said the collaboration will help speed up the development and deployment of web-based medical imaging applications.

articles.summary: Mytoka Petry, a Portland mom, was attacked by eight dogs on July 15 in North Portland, Oregon, leaving her with severe facial injuries, losing an arm and an ear and potentially losing her eye. She was rushed to hospital and is in intensive care, with two other people who intervened also injured. The dogs have since been taken into custody and are currently being held pending a formal investigation. Friends and family have organized a GoFundMe page to help Petry's family as she remains in hospital. While she is in a stable condition, doctors warn that she may face months in hospital and potentially lose her eye due to complications. The attack occurred at a homeless encampment and has been described as 'horrendous' by friends and family as a sign of crime and urban decay in Portland, a city plagued by homeless encampments and crime.

articles.description: Extra mosquito spraying will happen Thursday in Marlborough to control the adult population.
articles.content: MARLBOROUGH, MA — State health officials this week detected West Nile Virus in a mosquito sample taken on the west side of Marlborough, the first such instance of the rare but potentially serious dise... [1446 symbols]

entities.data: the state Department of Public Health
The Central Massachusetts Mosquito Control Project

articles.summary: State health officials have detected West Nile Virus in a mosquito sample taken on the west side of Marlborough, marking the first time this summer that the rare but potentially serious disease has been detected in the city. The state Department of Public Health announced that one sample taken July 19 tested positive. The Central Massachusetts Mosquito Control Project was planning to spray a residential area near Boston Post Road, Millham Street and Bigelow Street in case of adverse weather. The risk of human WNV in the Marlbor area was still rated "low" as of Thursday, according to DPH. The positive sample is among 27 found so far this summer across Massachusetts.

articles.title: Suffolk: Health trust says plans for new hospital still on track
articles.description: A Suffolk trust still hopes to have a new hospital by 2030, despite the government's national review of hospital plans.
articles.content: An NHS trust has urged the government not to "inadvertently slow the momentum" as it aims to build a new hospital. West Suffolk Hospital in Bury St Edmunds was one of 40 hospitals previously earmarked... [2373 symbols]
articles.summary: The West Suffolk NHS Foundation Trust (WSFT) has urged the government not to "inadvertently slow the momentum" as it aims to build a new hospital in Bury St Edmunds, one of 40 hospitals previously earmarked for a rebuild by 2030 by the previous Conservative government. Wes Streeting, Secretary of State for Health and Social Care, told Parliament that the new hospital programme was "not deliverable in that timeframe". However, a spokesman for WSFT stated that the trust remained on track to deliver a replacement hospital and that "great progress" had already been made. The trust has been making great progress with its plans to replace West Suffolk Hospital, which was built in the 1970s and has structural defects associated with reinforced autoclaved aerated concrete (RAAC) used in its roof and walls.

articles.summary: The West Suffolk NHS Foundation Trust (WSFT) has urged the government not to "inadvertently slow the momentum" as it aims to build a new hospital in Bury St Edmunds, one of 40 hospitals previously earmarked for a rebuild by 2030 by the previous Conservative government. However, Wes Streeting, Secretary of State for Health and Social Care, told Parliament that he believed the new hospital programme was not deliverable in that timeframe. A spokesman for WSFT stated that the trust remained on target to deliver a replacement hospital and that "great progress" had already been made. The trust has been making great progress with its plans to build the replacement hospital, with archaeological surveys, buffer tree planting and construction of a temporary access road either complete or advanced.

articles.title: Doctors blamed my daughter's neurological condition on watching TikTok
articles.description: Jessica Huitson, 15, from Newton Hall, Durham, (pictured right) was told her rare neurological condition was caused by 'watching too much TikTok'.
articles.content:
Doctors blamed a teenage girl's rare neurological condition on 'watching too much TikTok, her mother claims.

Helen Huitson's daughter, Jessica, ordeal started when she began experiencing 'strange' bo... [6456 symbols]
articles.summary: Helen Huitson's daughter, Jessica, developed a rare neurological condition, Paediatric Autoimmune Neuropsychiatric Disorders Associated with Streptococcal Infections (PANDAS), which is believed to be an autoimmune disorder and neuropsychiatric condition promoted by an abnormal immune response to infection. Jessica, now 15, became unable to control her body and began experiencing verbal tics, which included repeating apologies and abusive language. She also experienced non-epileptic seizures up to 120 a day. Despite multiple hospital visits, Jessica's mother was left distraught when doctors blamed her daughter's suffering on 'anxiety'. She was later privately diagnosed with PANDAS. The condition most commonly occurs after a strep infection and can cause brain inflammation if the body's immune system mistakenly attacks healthy brain cells. There are no formal medical guidelines for diagnosis in the UK.

articles.title: New Study Evaluates Use of the Nerivio® REN Wearable for Treatment of Migraine in Children Under the Age of 12
articles.description: Theranica, a neuromodulation therapeutics company, today announced that Annals of the Child Neurology Society has published results from a prospective real-world evidence study evaluating the safety and efficacy of remote electrical neuromodulation (REN) as a treatment for migraine in children ages 6 to 11. The Nerivio® REN wearable is the first FDA-cleared, non-drug, easy-to-use treatment for both acute migraine attacks and prevention of migraine with or without aura in adolescents and adults a
articles.content:
Nerivio, currently indicated for use in ages 12 and older, demonstrates study results in younger children with migraine.

BRIDGEWATER, N.J. and NETANYA, Israel, July 25, 2024 /PRNewswire/ -- , a neuro... [4857 symbols]
articles.summary: Theranica, a neuromodulation therapeutics company, has published results from a prospective real-world evidence study evaluating the safety and efficacy of the Nerivio REN wearable device for migraine in children ages 6 to 11. The study found that 72.2% of patients reported pain relief, 36.0% achieved pain freedom, 83.3% experienced functional disability relief, and 38.9% achieved functional disability freedom. The device was used as a standalone treatment in 45.1% of cases and combined with over-the-counter medications in 34.2%, with 79.3%. No adverse events were reported, demonstrating the REN's safety and effectiveness. Theranica is currently under FDA review to possibly expand the indication to ages eight years of age and older.

entities.data: The Central Massachusetts Mosquito Control Project

articles.summary: State health officials have detected West Nile Virus in a mosquito sample taken near Grove Street in Worcester, marking the first time in the city of the disease so far this summer. Two samples taken on July 19 tested positive, according to the state Department of Public Health. The Central Massachusetts Mosquito Control Project plans to spray an area between Edgeworth and Salisbury streets west of I-190 to control the mosquito population. While WNV can infect people of all age, it can cause fever, flu-like illness, and severe illness in rare cases. The risk of human WNV in the Worcester area was rated "low" as of Thursday. The state has also confirmed 14 positive Eastern Equine Encephalitis samples in mosquitoes this summer, all found in Plymouth County.

articles.title: Men who plotted to import drugs in car jailed
articles.description: Matthew Woods and Kurt Hughes are jailed for importing almost £100,000 of cocaine to the island.
articles.content:
Matthew Woods, Kurt Hughes and Daniel Moody were sentenced for the plot on Wednesday [BBC]

A man has been jailed for 18 years and nine months for a plot to import large quantities of cocaine and cann... [2365 symbols]
articles.summary: Matthew Woods, Kurt Hughes and Daniel Moody have been sentenced to 18 years and nine months in relation to a plot to import large quantities of cocaine and cannabis to the Isle of Man hidden in a car. Woods was involved in smuggling almost £100,000 worth of cocaine into the island on 6 June 2022, while Hughes, whose garage was used to hide the drugs, was jailed for 10 years and eight months. Moody was sentenced to four years for helping to package the cannabis. Both Moody and Hughes were also given exclusion orders from returning to the island following their release.

articles.title: Men who plotted to import drugs in car into Isle of Man jailed

Hughes pleaded guilty to charges of being concerned in the importation of cocaine and the importation of cannabis.

Moody, of Rock Ferry, Merseyside, was found guilty of playing a part in importing th... [1276 symbols]
articles.summary: Two men have been sentenced to life imprisonment for conspiring to import drugs into the Isle of Man, with Hughes pleading guilty to charges of being concerned in the importation of cocaine and cannabis. Moody was found guilty of playing a part in importing cannabis, while Woods was convicted of being involved in both the importations of both drugs and both cocaine. Woods was also convicted of causing grievous bodily harm while on bail for the drugs offences. Moody and Hughes were also given exclusion orders forbidding them from returning to the Isle Of Man for five years following their release.

articles.title: Probe launched after female inmate dies amid spate of prisoner deaths
articles.description:
A probe has been launched after a female inmate died at a jail hit by a spate of prisoner deaths.
Sarah Boyle, 35, was discovered at HMP Styal, in Cheshire and died in hospital on July 20.
articles.content:
A probe has been launched after a female inmate died at a jail which has been plagued by a spate of prisoner deaths.

Sarah Boyle, 35, was found collapsed at HMP Styal, a women's prison in Wilmslow, C... [5461 symbols]
articles.summary: A probe has been launched after a female inmate, Sarah Boyle, died at HMP Styal, a women's prison in Wilmslow, Cheshire. Boyle was found collapsed and later died at Wythenshawe Hospital. Her death was reportedly self-inflicted. The Prison Service confirmed Boyle's death and a probe will be conducted by the Prisons and Probation Ombudsman (PPO). This is the latest in a series of deaths at the jail, where there have been at least 11 suicides since 2007. Former inmates have described the prison as 'hell on earth' and 'no place for a vulnerable young woman'.

articles.summary: Wildfires in several western states and Canada are causing severe air quality alerts and evacuation orders across the western United States. The National Interagency Fire Center reported there are 79 large, active wildfires that have burned over 1.4 million acres across the country. Evacuation orders are in effect for 15 fires in the Northwest. Meanwhile, Canada is battling about 430 active wildfires in British Columbia and 177 in Alberta, including two that have led to the evacuation of up to 25,000 visitors and residents of the Canadian Rockies’ largest national park. To deal with the pollution from these wildfires, many air quality advisories have been issued in many western states.

articles.title: Patient’s payout after routine dental surgery could shorten his life by five years
articles.description: Gerry White received £50,000 in February after dental treatment resulted in an ongoing abscess
articles.content: A retired paramedic has received a £50,000 settlement from a dentist after a root canal treatment left him hospitalised for weeks with a missing tooth and a heart infection which may have shortened hi... [7006 symbols]
articles.summary: Retired paramedic Gerry White, 65, has received a £50,000 settlement from a dentist after a root canal treatment in 2012 left him hospitalised for weeks with a missing tooth and a heart infection that may have shortened his life by five years. The incident occurred after dental treatment at Rodericks Dental Partners in Stockport, Greater Manchester, resulted in an ongoing abscess that caused infective endocarditis, a potentially fatal inflammation of the heart valves' lining. This infection put him in hospital for six weeks and left him with a heart valve replacement surgery in June 2018. Specialist dental negligence solicitors, Dental Law Partnership, revealed that a poorly performed root canal procedure by the dental practice was responsible for the life-threatening infection. Gerry, who lives with his wife Louise and two grandchildren, expressed his relief at receiving the compensation and hopes to encourage others to check their teeth for signs of health issues.

articles.title: Exclusive: USWNT Forward Shares Her Over-The-Top Nighttime Routine
articles.description: Ahead of the Paris games, USWNT star Mallory Swanson shares the workouts and treatments that get her ready.
articles.content: In Chill Chat, Bustle sits down with stars to chat about all things wellness, from skin care products to hacks for getting a good nights sleep. Here, USWNT forward Mallory Swanson shares her game-day ... [5856 symbols]
articles.summary: USWNT forward Mallory Swanson has been a rising star in soccer since making her international debut with the U.S. Women’s National Team in 2016 at age 17. However, she missed the last two major international tournaments due to injury, including a hip injury and a tear to her patellar tendon. She credits her comeback to mental fortitude and a hyperbaric chamber, PEMF energy mats, and lots of red light therapy for her recovery. She also shares her sleep routine, which includes a nighttime bath and a sauna. Swanson also discusses her game-day rituals and the breathwork technique that has helped her develop her game.

articles.title: Oooh arrrrgh! Doctors remove 18-inch vegetable from farmer's rear
articles.description: The 60-year-old patient from Chhatarpur district of Madhya Pradesh in India called an ambulance to his farm on Sunday after suffering from severe stomach pain
articles.content:
Shocked medics have had to perform surgery a farmer after discovering an 18-inch long vegetable that was stuck in his backside.

The 60-year-old patient from Chhatarpur district of Madhya Pradesh in I... [1993 symbols]
articles.summary: A 60-year-old farmer from Chhatarpur district of Madhya Pradesh, India, underwent surgery after suffering from severe stomach pain. Doctors discovered the cause of the discomfort after an X-ray and discovered an 18-inch long vegetable, a bottle gourd or lauki, had been rammed through his rectum and stuck in his anal cavity. Surgeons at the District Hospital Chhatarur (DHC) performed a two-and-a-half hour operation to remove the foreign object. The patient is currently in a stable condition and recovering well under the care of the doctors. The hospital is investigating the circumstances surrounding the incident.

articles.title: California man’s medically assisted death offers lessons for everyone
articles.description: While practice is legal in this state, unnecessary hurdles threaten to prolong the suffering of the terminally ill
articles.content: My husband, Gary, was diagnosed with Stage 4 lymphoma in 2019, at the age of 57. Gary was a vegan, an artist and graphic designer and an avid hiker. He loved life, and we did everything we could to ex... [4312 symbols]

entities.data: the End of Life Option Act

articles.summary: Trudy Pachonon's husband, Gary, was diagnosed with Stage 4 lymphoma at age 57 and underwent numerous treatments for the disease, including chemotherapy and a bone marrow transplant. Despite his efforts, the cancer returned in 2023 and he continued to fight, but a scan revealed the disease was drug-resistant. The couple learned that medically assisted death was legal in California, and Kaiser Permanente had an end-of-life options program. California enacted the End of Life Option Act in 2016, allowing residents with terminal illnesses with a life expectancy of six months or less to request medication that will hasten their death. However, there is limited public awareness about such a practice, with only a quarter of California seniors polled even knowing about it. Pachachon's wife, Trudy, found End Of Life Choices California and volunteer, Lynne Calkins, to help Gary end his life with dignity. Despite these hurdles, she hopes their story helps Californians understand their options and resolve their own suffering.

articles.content: Yep, not dead yet. The surgery apparently went well and while I am in pain and getting used to my new body (The bits they took out were fairly important. The options left behind take some work to repl... [2842 symbols]
articles.summary: The author reflects on the struggles of recuperating at the hospital, where rest and walking were difficult due to an IV and heart monitor, which made walking and taking care of myself almost impossible. The hospital constantly interrupted by tests and medicine delivery schedules, which led to numerous interruptions. The author credits nurses and technicians for their ability to schedule these schedules and communicate with the doctors about her situation. She also credits them with making her conformable and providing information about the surgery and her recovery. Despite her struggles, the author acknowledges that nurses are underpaid and underappreciated and that they deserve better pay and working conditions. Support these nurses for advocating for better treatment and increased focus on single patients.
